This is a bloody brilliant game.

Satisfactory feels like two titles merged into one.
In the first, you'll be creating the factory, which presents a series of growing challenges to your building and organizational skills, as you are tasked to set up complex production lines, made up by increasingly large machines that will require a vast amount of space and complex logistics.
Tech progress is made up of milestones, that you can unlock in the order you prefer (most of the time) by submitting specific products, and which in turn make you able to manufacture complex parts that will be required to unlock the next tier of technology. Such tiers bring about veritable revolutions in how your factory needs to work, and present whole new sets of challenges.

About this first aspect, as an avid player of building games like Fallout 4, Subnautica, Raft and Valheim, i must say Satisfactory may well have the best system i have ever worked with. The way things snap into place while still giving you flexibility and providing cues that facilitate orderly allignment, is near-perfect (yes i think i said pretty much the same thing about Valheim but Satisfactory is even better).
It's also deeply appreciable that can you replace things like conveyor belts with their improved counterparts without having to dismantle them first. You're going to have to built a LOT of conveyor belts.

In the second game, you'll be exploring the untamed wilderness (you start out by foot but can unlock a rather satisfying choice of vehicles and accessories like a jetpack), looking for resources and special items (some of which are still work in progress and not used but hey, can't hurt to stock up in advance) and defending yourself from aggressive fauna as you discover a world that is absolutely beautiful, often breathtakingly so, spanning from grasslands and forests that look like a mix of Pandora and Halo, to desert-like biomes, wetlands, swamps and volcanic valleys. Obtaining the special items will often require you to overcome a combination of challenges like reaching high places, surviving toxic gases, clearing boulders and beating particularly nasty encounters.

The map is truly vast and gave me a sense of wide-eyed exploration akin to that of Subnautica (but without the terror because technically it is you who are the threat to the world this time XD).
And finally, the soundtrack does it's job damn well, switching dynamically as you are either working in the factory or out in the field.

Satisfactory is definitely one of those games that i will keep installed forever, returning to it again and again. If you like building games you MUST have it.

One of the best open world survival-craft games that I have ever played. Your job is to scavange for resources and use those resources to make the parts required in order to unlock more blueprints to make better use of the resources available to you. But what makes this game different from other open world survival-craft games is that you can automate evrything. You can build machines with the blueprints that you unlock and let the machines do all the work for you so you can sit back and relax while draining the planet from its resources more efficiently. But the planet that you were sent to is not that safe. You must fight with some locals that are trying to protect the resources of their planet. Luckily you don't have to build walls or turrets because once you get rid of them they won't respawn and they don't damage buildings anyways because they are dumb. This game offers infinite possibilities with its large world and building mechanics. You can build whatever you want in this game. You can build tiny starter production lines or massive factories but you'll probably give up on trying to make your creations look good and end up building huge pile of spaghetties. You have to find creative ways to move the resources or the parts because resources are scattered all around the world. You can use conveyors, trains or even drones. Getting good at the game and finally building something decent will probably take a long time but once you get the taste of accomplishing something you will realize that it was all worth it.

Final Verdict:
Satisfactory is a beautiful game with an amazing community (the discord is great) of both kidders and players. The Mod tool is super easy, just click the mods you want and restart the game (although some mods can cause crashes and other issues). It has bugs and the Epic-Steam multiplayer is terrible and takes forever to troubleshoot, if your getting it from recommendation of going to recommend it to a friend, make sure they get it on the same platform as you. The graphics are cool and impressive, the music and sound effects are good as well; There’s also a nice photomode that can be used while moving to helpfully allow you to zoom in. No payment required after buying the game and all updates are free, the devs clearly care a TON about the game and are pretty transparent with future updates, doing weekly update videos and engaging with the community.All around amazing game that I’m extremely glad to own.

Now you know that Josh made a pretty good representation of the game when he can make a conveyor belt cocoon to pretty much nowhere, be the leading exporter of nuclear waste and have the devs put it in their preview pictures.

So, Satisfactory. A few of my friends would sometimes call this Factorio 3D, but it really isn't. There are many mechanics in this game that differ from Factorio. You have hyper tubes to transport you between many areas, the buildings you need can be instantly built as long as you have the resources for it and conveyor belts can be on top of another conveyor belt. All of this really cool.

Now, if you think the map is procedurally generated, it isn't. When I learned that when I started several saves, I felt like it was a bit of a letdown. Maybe they plan to make ice or different worlds later after the early access game is complete?

The main goal of the game is to dig up resources and reach all of the milestones available in the game, all while delivering things to space with a giant space elevator. All for the sake of filling the ever necessary demands of the consumer.

The game is just fun. I have nothing bad to say about it, other than that I wish Other than that, great game. 9/10.

This game is highly recommended. It’s quite challenging, especially in the beginning. Things I particularly appreciated are that the game world is beautiful, the game is generous to the player, not punishing, and the construction and tech tree make sense. Of course some suspension of disbelief is required, as when one pushes a button and a nuclear plant grows from a collection of steel beams and other parts.

The game is intellectually challenging as well as presenting challenging amounts of risk. At times I found my attention riveted to the play.

The game world is very detailed and cleverly worked out with a lavish amount of attention paid.
Though the game is classified as being in early access status, it shows a high degree of polish. If you’re interested, you should buy this game while it’s in early access, before the price goes up. I can’t honestly think that much more will be added.

Satisfactory is one of those games where you say you'll play for "Just an hour," play for a bit, then look up at the clock and realise you've been playing for 9 hours straight. That's not a bad thing if you keep that in mind before starting a session, because that time pays you back with the satisfaction of watching your well made factory manufacture highly complex parts from raw materials. Or, as with my playthroughs, start with a plan, then vastly underestimate your logistics requirements and watch as your beautiful factory spirals into a maze of conveyor belts and scaffolding. The game requires a lot of thinking and a bit of calculation to get things flowing smoothly, but that's the biggest part of the fun in my opinion.

On another note, the assets and gameplay elements that Coffee Stain adds always feel like they were tested properly and designed nicely well before their public release, which is pretty rare for an Early Access game. If the trailers or anything I've said here appeal to you, you'll probably enjoy this game.

This game is 10x more fun with friends but also amazing on your own. The abuse of physics in multiplayer is great. The quiet grind by yourself is great. If you want to full nerd out, can I suggest drawing out the P&ID of your process on grid paper or perhaps writing a Python script to suggest minimum input for your required output.

The game is worth it at full price. If you tell yourself to get it on sale, just buy it now. The $$ you'll save won't be worth it for how much fun you're going to have.

It looks nice, it's well executed in many ways (and cheesy in a few others, but it's a beta), but at the very core, it's an idle game. There are, like in any idle game, a few superficial choices you can do to be more efficient, and it keeps you busy so you don't get bored in between the craftly intervalled drops of dopamine the game design is centered on delivering. Reward/unlock are spaced so that you can nearly access the next upgrade, just play 5 more minutes etc.

But can you lose? No you can't. Can you embrace a variety of approaches? Absolutely not. Just build, farm, build, farm, connect, connect, connect. It's not a game as much as it is a toy.

It's a reasonably cool toy though. You can chill building what is indeed a satisfying factory. Not a clever one, not a challenging one, but yours truly, and there's joy in that.

Still, the game take an awful lot of time to make you on the whole dumber. If you have any self estem, or don't fancy to be a dopamine junky, skip.

This game has a long, LONG way to go.

-The UI is cumbersome due to the 1st person perspective. I get what they were going for, more of a real survival experience compared to Factorio's 3rd person perspective. But it is very time consuming and tedious to place/route conveyors cleanly.

-The 'buildings' just float in the air without the need for any support whatsoever. You can take the time to make it 'look right' but it doesn't actually matter. Places floors, build a factory, delete floors. Magical floating factory of magic. Yay, science.

-The assemblers take inputs on one side and outputs out the other, making assembly lines very bland and lacking in creativity. The robotic inserters of Factorio provide a much wider range of arrangement options between chains of assemblers which allows for a broader range of creativity and problem-solving for the players. These 'In on the left, out on the right' assemblers make building assembly lines a boring grind with little in the way of limiting factors beyond time/effort.

-It lacks a means to copy/paste groups of assemblers already built in tight, efficient layouts, forcing you to make additional copies manually, click by click.

-The tech is laid out poorly, unlocking things that would be very useful in the mid-game only in the late-game when they are no longer of any use to you.

-The late game just keeps scaling up the volume of items needed, but with a lacking mechanic to copy/paste groups of assemblers, it's just a grind to build more copies of each thing one at a time to meet the late-game demands.

-The vehicle transport systems to carry resources between outposts are pointless. Sure the vehicles transport items faster than a belt, but the truck stations only have ONE belt for input or output, so it is still bound by a 1-belt bottleneck. There is no difference between a truck route and simply a very long belt between outposts. This shows the devs are adding features 'because it would be cool' instead of a calculated functional niche it is to fill.

-The map is fixed, non-procedural and has massive holes to oblivion in it. There are waterfalls which rain down on to dry land. There are rivers/streams which are too shallow to be harvested as a water supply and thus completely pointless.

-The day/night cycle adds nothing to the game experience. Nothing is different between these two times. No predators come out at night, etc. Nothing changes. It's just dark, and you turn on your head lamp. The lamps/lighting you can build to combat the darkness in the factory is ... poorly done. Each light consumes ONE MEGAWATT of power. It's easy for the lighting to consume more power than the actual factory. Fortunately, they added a light switch to the game, but still... 1MW light bulbs? Really? Come on. Also these 1MW light bulbs illuminate very small areas, so you need a lot of them. And the game engine obviously has a hard limit on how many light sources it can render because you can see lights that are 'on' but not casting light until you get closer. It just looks bad.


This game has some good working features.

-It hasn't crashed or frozen on me yet.
-The multiplayer runs well with my friends.
-Performance is smooth even when streaming.
-No glaring memory leaks.
-The Hard Drives you can find through exploration allow you to unlock alternative recipes for various components, allowing for a unique combination of recipes, and thus a unique play-through factory design experience, each time you play. That's a really good idea.
-The 'company store' as a means to buy/unlock various equipment upgrades is also a good mechanic, allowing you to unlock just the tools you need/want and providing smaller-scale achievements/goals beyond the longer-term goals of unlocking the next tier.


All-in-all, I do not enjoy this game. The beginning is fun, as the effort versus reward is well balanced. But as the game progresses and resource logistics and demand scale up, but I still have to build everything one click at a time without the ability to copy/paste or blueprint layouts, the effort goes up exponentially while the reward does not. Then it is many hours, or even days, of grind to unlock one more step forward. Not worth it. The game has potential, but in its current state, it is a FAR inferior knock-off of Factorio or FortressCraft. Far inferior.

Don't buy it yet. Make the devs earn the paycheck by actually finishing the game.

A great game, however a few problems. Lets start with the positives though!

The logistics through the game are pretty easy. They ramp up eventually, but the game makes it easy to ramp up products and get you engaged in trying to make things as ratio'd up as possible. Brilliant tools to use, such as zip line (which I know is a new addition), blade runners, re-bar gun and a host of other things really makes you think about what you need to carry and use to do each part of the job well.

The game is only around 40% logistics though, to begin with. The map is beautiful, and very atmospheric. Danger feels like it is around the corner all the time, but then you also feel free to jump and explore all the time. So much vegetation is abundant in each area making it feel alive.

Multiplayer is fun. Go off, explore each going their own way, with their own projects, all to make the final product faster and more rich. A dedicated explorer and a dedicated builder ensures a massive collection radius of resources, locating ore points and scouting for new building areas, whilst the builder ensures the explorer has a home to come back to.

The 3D aspects of building, although looking daunting from the outset, is actually made very easy and simple with a huge range for building objects. The models and textures for the game are also very rich, and brings the factory to life.

With all this positivity I have to start with some bad parts. There is only one map, and this on its own is not bad. It is a great map, very large, lots to explore. Hand crafted. But this is where it falls down. If it was procedurally generated I could happily give a pass, but its hand crafted.
So why, oh why, do we have floating grass? We have elongated textures in some harder to reach but still easily accessible places where the cliff face should be cliff, but its clear its an elongated grass structure. We have hidden power slugs still underneath terrain. Two resource nodes too close to each other to use both at the same time (that I've come across, possibly more!). This is a hand crafted map. It should receive more love over the 2 years then it has.

Also where are the extra maps? 2 years, no extra maps? Or teasing for extra maps? Or DLC maps? Nothing? I'm happy to give them a pass on this one, under the guise that they want to make sure that everything else in the game is polished before they add more maps so that everything on a new map can be balanced. But I've had the game for less then 100 hours and I feel like I've seen everything on this map now... I feel ready for a change.

AI mapping and attack sequences still appear to be missing in some areas. One enemy type literally just 'floats' about, no animations what-so-ever. I'd be happy to say it was just me, but I've seen it on a friends machine too. 2 years to add some animations to an enemy? Because this enemy has been in the game since launch too. AI tends to stick to zones which is fine, pretty standard in most games... But I've also seen the enemy run directly away from me outside of their supposed zone to... ???

The prices of the logistics ramp up very quickly. It can go from needing a couple of iron spots to needing at least 20 to keep the later mechanics going at a pace. Spent a long time just setting up the expansion of industry which is pretty much copy-paste other areas I've already built. Doesn't sound too bad, apart from there is no copy-paste function or blueprint function that I've found in game. Quite happy to say we can only copy stuff on foundations etc etc or any limitations, but if you have a factory game Factorio set the standard, and that standard now includes copy-paste...
In the past I'd have happily spammed the left click for foundations, but now that should be base game to easily expand areas rather then rely on mods to fill these spots. This goes for a lot of the little problems with building, "Oh there is a mod for that" should not be a go-to response.

Models are... Boring? They all do the same thing, again and again and again. For the smelters this is okay, we are smelting ore. Ore goes in, ingots come out. There is no animation. But you've provided one on most of the other machines, and these animations should respect the recipes set. The production of a rotor should get a different animation over reinforced plate, and so on and again. This will really cement the idea that your factory is alive and allow you to see from a glance what the machine is actually doing.
The last issue I have with models is clipping. You don't allow clipping through other models but terrain is fine? Wires dangling through foundations? There is little consistency here that needs tightening up, don't allow clipping through terrain (either by just don't let us or add extra supports) or allow us to clip through everything.

This leads onto trains. Now spamming signals everywhere seems like a bad idea in this game, however you could program the rails to add them in dynamically or something. But to have no clipping trains? They feel very cheaty.
This then leads onto a lack of a logic system. Okay this is a stretch of a lead, but if a train isn't full of a product I would rather it didn't leave a station. And this starts to lead onto a lot of the other industries. I can't store only a little bit of product, its a full cargo container or nothing. Automated power systems are not a thing, I.E. Power is dipping under a certain point, please stop supplying the grid until you've recovered your own personal area of power. Okay, we can separate grids and I would honestly suggest to any players to place their coal miners and water extractors on a separate grid, but can we not logic that? Well no, because that system isn't in the game...

And lastly multiplayer. I already know they have said they are still working on the code. But when you load into a world and I can not see what products are on a belt it makes me feel like the factory has died, and took me a while to realise that the items were just not visually loading in for me.

It is a good game. But I would love to see just a little more effort on what is in the game at the moment over adding more mechanics for mechanics sake.

Very chilling game with very fun construction and logical depenndencies that force you to cosntantly update your factory design.

Many interesting building as well as Satisfactory (lol) progression of multiple tiers and sub-tiers.

There is also beautiful landscape which if fun for exploration as well as some light combat elements (basically the combat is only started on your initiative, because you can easily run away from combat if you don't want to fight).

Last, but not least, this is the first game which made me regret cutting down entire forest to make space for my factory.

As of this writing it's still a little rough around the edges, but if you want a beautiful, humorous, somewhat less complex and less combat/defense oriented take on Factorio or Minecraft tech mods, this is it.

To be clear it's plenty complex enough, and if you've done something like Technic mod pack in Minecraft it'll feel very familiar, down to many of the basic game mechanics, technology tiers, and resources. It's just not quite as deep as Factorio, which is not necessarily a bad thing! Satisfactory is more approachable and lower pressure overall, while still leaving plenty of room to obsessively optimize and build ridiculously massive factories.

If you're looking for combat, look elsewhere. At the moment it seems tacked on and shallow. Monsters do not attack (and cannot damage) your base, and mostly serve as occasional annoyances while you're trying to build your rural infrastructure or as trivial obstacles to resources. Fighting them is clunky - you're hilariously ill-equipped for it, but on the other hand their AI is basic AF so once you figure out their patterns it's easy enough to deal with them. If it weren't for the fact that they drop a few items you need in small quantities, I'd rather they didn't exist.

Satisfactory vs Factorio

The chances are that if you've found yourself looking at Satisfactory, you also know about Factorio. Being a Factorio player, I was intrigued by Satisfactory because as good as the former is, you soon find yourself wanting to do things like build multi-level conveyor systems, which leads onto thoughts of a 3D automation game.

So here we are, 3D Factorio right? Well, no. Satisfactory is a bit of a slow starter; the initial premise is the same - you've arrived on an alien world with little more than a toolbelt and a bit of knowledge. You're going to need to collect raw resources with your bare hands, and assemble them into something useful. At this point, Factorio isn't fully committed to trying to kill you - whereas Satisfactory will start to try and do that pretty much straight away (depending where on the map you go). Fortunately you have a handy stick and once you understand how they work, the initial enemies are reasonably straightforward to dispatch. It's worth mentioning here that where Factorio provides you a random world, Satisfactory's is very much hand crafted - it might lower replayability in the long run, but it looks great and offers some early challenge moving around (and remembering where you came from).

Shortly after finding your feet, you'll be directed to, or will have managed to build an iron miner, a smelter, and a belt between the two. This is much the same in both games, automation at last! Obviously not forgetting that you need to hook machines up to power poles, and your early power stations - biomass burners, need feeding with leaves and wood collected by hand.

This is where the games start to diverge again; in that now, you're quite comfortable with the enemies you're fighting in Satisfactory and you've largely worked out that they protect certain areas, and don't come and attack you or your factory. In the other game, you might have started having to repel your first waves of the bitey things which will keep coming and keep destroying your stuff.

It's at this point where Factorio ramps up the complexity; lots of machines required to build lots of components, to go into machines and ever refine into more specialist components - Satisfactory follows the same path but more gently, the production chains aren't that long or complex - at first it will be a simple transformation of one part to another (ore->ingots) and then onto machines than can combine two, then three, and four comes near the end of the research tree. It's not trying to kill you constantly (to the point where you can leave the game running and know you're safe), and so you can enjoy it as a rather relaxing (and very pretty) factory building game. There's always stuff to do, but much of it is making things look nice, tweaking them for efficiency, refueling your power set up, and leveling up by sending your components back through the space elevator you've by now built. You'll enjoy building factories on top of factories if you so want, whether you have a single large building or lots of little focussed installations at various places is up to you. Your ore miners never 'run out' in Satisfactory, so whether things work or they don't, are currently powered or not, makes little difference as long as you can go and get the things out of them that you need.

I like my games complex a lot of the time (never needlessly so) and hence made the comparison between what is on paper, two very similar games. What I have found though, is that whilst I will go back to Factorio and try to further that game - I've really enjoyed a quite, well, satisfying experience with this game.

I think I'm near the end of Satisfactory; and I think it's near the end of it's development cycle. What remains to be seen is whether it's replayable in its current state (and whether I'd want to), or what the developers add in the finished game to make you want to go through it all again and again.

That said, in one playthrough I have more than had my money's worth and so heartily recommend this to anyone.

TL;DR:
- Satisfactory is 3D and allows you to build upwards and outwards and enhance your spaghetti mess like never before. It looks lovely and runs well.
- Satisfactory tries to kill you early on; but overall is far less threatening than Factorio which will kill you and destroy your factory.
- If you die in Satisfactory, you respawn and go to loot your stuff. In Factorio, you die and have to reload a save or start again.
- In satisfactory, your automation setup feels less complex than Factorio. There's precious little filtering (but some) and lines that effectively handle multiple products (you can split and merge but 'smart splitting' is fairly advanced in an optional research tree). And there's plenty of room not to cram everything into a small space anyway.
- Factorio has lots of logic stuff going on and really programmable machines, I have seen no evidence of that in Satisfactory. It's not a bad thing, just different. This is less hardcore.
- The two games are different enough that if you like the genre, you might like both and it's worth owning both. They may compete in the same space but they also compliment each other, with sufficient differences in how they play out.

I scoffed when I saw reviews claiming that "Satisfactory was always on their mind and they spent their days consumed with thoughts of the next phase of their factory's construction." I dismissed these views as the deranged ravings of rabid fans, the like of which you only find lurking on fanatical subreddits.

I don't know when they started. The voices, I mean. Now when I get into bed I hear them all competing: "what're we going to do with the heavy residual oil?" "We should expand the coal power plant, the current output isn't fit for purpose." "The belt capacity alone won't support more factories!" "When are we going to connect the secondary sites with transport tubes?" "With a throughput of 200 screws a minute we'll barely be achieving an output of 8 rotors!"

Now I go to sleep thinking about it. I think about the next project; I think about laying the foundations; I think about the splits required; I think about the input quantities and byproduct mitigation. I think about the areas I still need to explore; the beacons I need to collect; the components my factory hasn't automated yet.

And, after the thoughts stop, I dream about it. I dream of the resources moving along the conveyors. I dream of the recipes and the options. I dream of the travel tubes I'm going to put down. I honestly wish this hadn't happened, but it has.

But how can I not dream about it? When you look back at your factories, no matter how messy or spaghetti-reliant, they still look marvellous. You'll walk amongst the chimney spires belching smoke, ride the conveyors with the inputs, gaze at the increasingly intricate production lines. After the dust has settled and the uranium rods come rolling out for the first time, you won't be able to help but think "I am a god and all will marvel at my work."

Here's the thing about Satisfactory, what passes for combat and enemy AI is anything but. There's always a group of enemies guarding every node (at least the five or so that I found in the admittedly tiny amount of time I could put up with this game) you have only a taser with a nonexistent range to fight them with (I was standing in front of one of these enemies who couldn't enter the room portion of the tier 3 HUB and couldn't hit them but they could hit me, it was directly in front of me and I had to basically walk into the character model in order to land a hit) so you die basically every time one of these things aggros on you.

They also chase you ENDLESSLY, you have to die to get them to stop at which point they return to their original spawn point, which is on top of a resource node, effectively making that node useless unless you want to dig up as much as you can before you die then try and retrieve it from your corpse and run out of the aggro range before the enemy kills you again. The combat and enemy AI which is basically just endlessly chasing and attacking anything that enters aggro range, is completely unbearable and makes the fun stuff impossible to enjoy, purchase refunded. Maybe I'll try again if I ever hear that they fixed this. No I'm not interested in a peaceful mode, I'm interested in enemies that I can actually fight off or at least run away from.

-I have always enjoyed these types of games. Making larger and larger factories to create more and more products to sell in order to get stuff that allows you to create larger factories. But as fleshed out as this seems and as good as it looks, I'll be looking for another game. There is only one reason for that... the power system.
-I got all the way up to coal power which helps A LOT. The system before then is so horrible. It required me to constantly micromanage my generators by deforesting everything the eye can see, then crafting the leaves and wood into biofuel and running around, filling generators every 30 minutes.
-With that said coal still has it's problems, no matter how hard I try there is no good way to organize cables or coal generators. It is always a mess.
-It's hard to put into words why I dislike the system so much. All I can say is I spent about an hour organizing a new setup and I was excited to see how well it worked. But then I was stuck messing with the power for another 2 hours.

I wish there was a way to turn off the power requirement system entirely in a world.
There are other similar games that just give you the satisfaction of organizing a factory without this system .

Or here is another fix. Allow me to connect coal generators to 1 pole allowing for everything connected to that pole to be 150 max watts instead of 75. But allow it to work with infinite amount of generators.

Fun game about extracting resources from nodes and using different buildings to convert those resources into other resources that are then converted in other buildings which are then put into a resource sink to get tickets so you can buy stuff. All while trying to figure out how much of each resource you need and how to connect everything, while maintaining enough power for the buildings to consume and keep working.
There's also exploration, the map is hand made and quite nice. There are also things hidden across the map to find that will help boost your factory's productivity (power slugs, crash sites).
Overall I recommend and look forward to seeing new content and WIP content being fully implemented.

There are many ways to play this game. I started off trying to be 'efficient' and 'quick'. This got tiresome for me, but there's a lot of depth there given some of the math and the algorithm challenge of setting up efficient - and in some cases, super complicated - factory lines.

Then I went whole hog art project, and have really enjoyed the creative limitations as far as what you can and can't do and how to work around those limitations. This game has become a box of legos that do things, and I have found that immensely satisfying, and have tossed 'efficiency' out the window.

Satisfactory is a factory building game where you start with nothing on a strange new world with a goal of building parts for some corporations. You start out small building miners and assembly lines, but as you progress into the game, your components get more and more complicated to make necessitating improvements to your complex supply chains.

At its core, Satisfactory is an immensely satisfying puzzle game where you trying to find the best ways to maximize your factories, regulate power, and explore the new world.
I love the fact its like Subnautica, but on land. Very fun, but time consuming. Also a pain in the neck when you run out and die.

My experience with this game has been, for the most part, quite good. There were some frustrations that came from the learning curve, but nothing too drastic or overwhelming. Figuring out how to maximize and manage your processes can be quite fun and engaging. Plus, the inherent adventure of exploring the world and handling its challenges was immense fun.
However, this comes to a screeching halt with the final challenge of the game. The complexity and magnitude of the requirements for it spikes to levels beyond ridiculous. If I have to sit down with a XL spreadsheet and a calculator while not even playing the game just to figure out how many DAYS of letting the game run by itself 24-7 under optimal conditions to accomplish the FIRST of four final goals... it all turns into a mountain of "I don't want to do ANY of this".
I am aware this game is in early access and being adjusted and improved as we speak. However, as of now, I cannot recommend Satisfactory. The satisfaction does not last.

Perfect game. There are not many games that are this addictive, while making you build towards something great and visible in the process. This is the good kind of engaging game; unlike other games that use cheap tactics to keep you addicted. This really taps into you craving for intellectual challenge. And you'll be proud of your results after every session. There is always room for improving your production lines, and that will keep you coming back for another session of flow and focus... all this, while having a relaxing experience of concentration.

Solid functionality while in Early Access. The base game runs well in Single Player. Multiplayer still a little glitchy.

On Launch, I'll be waiting for:

Fully fleshed out story / environment: Coffee Stain has used lots of placeholder things that have promise.

Replayability: Once you've made a factory that does "all the things," it's hard to imagine why you'd load the game back up. The game needs some valid reason for zeroing out the research and buildings to start all the way back at Square One, or a reason to keep engaging with a complete factory.

Right now, I can recommend this Early Access title. Even if there was that thing with E.G.

We'll have to see after launch if that changes.

What can I say that hasn't been said about this game already...

You know, I'll say this, then. The game is fantastic. It really does steal your time. What I enjoy most, is that once you set your factory up perfectly, you can simply let it do it's thing, while you go out and explore the map. Since the 4 starting areas are just points to begin on the grander scale of the big map (32km^2), wherever you start, you'll be able to access the entirety of the map. So you can explore, gather up hard drives from crashed pods, or power slugs to overclock your machines.

And the machines really are the heart and soul of the game. They are so well animated, and the rush of getting everything to line up perfectly with 100% efficiency is one I never expected to love.

Clock speeds of machines is something that seems simple at first, but you realize that you can also manipulate power requirements of machines using it, to keep your power grid from getting overwhelmed.

Overall, I did not expect to love this game as much as I did. I bought it on Epic Games Store before it came to Steam, and bought it again once it hit Steam, since this was the only real reason I used Epic Games anyways. Definitely worth buying.

This game is by far the most visually appealing factory/logistics/automation game I have played. I love the dash of combat, and the exploration. The world is truly beautiful. Coffee Stain did a great job with this game. Even in Early Access, my experiences have been smooth, non-buggy hours of fun. With 95 total hours played, I need to bump my numbers up, but I am really enjoying the various aspects of this game.

I really like the in-game store concept that is implemented. By having a conveyor belt system discard your waste, you earn tickets and you can redeem them for additional cosmetic pieces, vice paying real $$$ for the cosmetics. You will need those pieces, because the world is massive and you can pretty much build anywhere, and your factories can be as large and spread out, or as condensed as you want them to be.

So the beginning of the game is pretty straight forward

Process item A to turn it into item B

Then eventually Combine item X and item Y and Get Z

However to do this on a sufficient scale you have to create factories, multiple buildings processing items in parallel.

The problem is that in the second half of the game things have to be processed in a crazy number of stages in varying proportions, that is not taking into account alternate recipe’s that, while simplifying the process, alter the proportions required. The game needs specifically on the higher tiers to make it easier to plan these long chains of stages to get to your desired items. You can try tools like or to try and plan out the factory, but there is no guarantee these tools are up-to-date.

As of Update 4

It’s enjoyable to a significant extent, there is a lot of potential and it seems they are rounding their late game setup, but if you are going to make it this in depth at the end you need something to help you plan.

Title : You want us to build here?

Graphics : *****
Gameplay : *****
U.I. : ****
GameMech : ****
Co-Play : Yes

(@) Early-Access, Update 4, 250+ hours playing at this point

(@) Overall:
Started just before Update 4 - with the drones and power revamp. If you loved Factorio, Love the old Minecraft Factory mods, you should enjoy this game as well. Still in early access, some quality of life improvements still need to be made.. Has some combat threats that can be handled with either pure physical responses or even planned ranged death. The belt connecting system is good, the transport system has many options to play with. Vehicles can be used to transport or explore the world.

(@) Pro:
The game has a good vibe for exploration and a wide expanse of a world. Plenty of places to go and see, different biomes to review and explore. I like to build with my friends, co-op is one of my big attractions.

(@) Cons:
Not being able to line your factory up very easily in the beginning. Some multiplayer bugs at this time cause strange things to happen, like out-of sync errors. I am hoping a quality of life update will fix these. No dedicated server option - that I know of, this would be great to run in the background.

TLDR: Missing mid-game quality of life features, thus forcing players to slowly do the same thing over and over again.

The first 20 hours are amazing. Having played hundreds of hours of Factorio in the few years leading up to Satisfactory's release, I had this one on my wishlist for a while as a possible 3D Factorio alternative. Now that I've played it, I can say this is way more than a mere 3D Factorio. This is an entirely different game and new experience. Added bonus: this game has stellar detail, graphics, and animations

I love how Satisfactory encourages the steady buildup of a factory. The tech tier unlocks usually transition you smoothly to an ever expanding factory in which you can go back to upgrade miners, double production, use faster belts, add more constructor machines, and expand into the distance for even more resources. It is also easy to get a perfect balance between miners and machines, and upgrading throughput is a simple matter of upgrading and/or overclocking a miner, then using the new raw ore to do whatever you need. This game provides a steady growth and expansion without ever feeling overwhelming. The game walks you through each new unlock by forcing you to build it before you can unlock the next tier. You can't simply research everything and then find yourself overwhelmed and unable to build. I never ran into a "what do I do next" confusion.

Instead, what I did run into was a mid-game terribly lacking every quality of life feature to make it worth playing. As I increased my ability to harvest resources, I also needed to increase the number of machines processing those resources. This involved an incessant rebuilding of the same layout over and over and over and over without end. Also missing is the ability to duplicate vehicle automation to have two or more vehicles perform the same function.

I don't see myself ever finishing the game unless this monotony is removed by fixing:
- Lack of blueprints drives repeatedly building the same setup over and over and over.
- Lack of map to show what obstacles may be in your way to get to that node that is 1800m away.
- Forced to spread far and wide to find all resources, but lack of fast travel options to quickly get around to your different outposts.
- Not everything can snap in place, making alignment sometimes difficult.

I was looking for a quality timesink in 2020, and here in 2021 it's looking like i'm still gonna need one. This is easily one of if not the best management and development experiences i have had in a video game. It's not very hard on your wallet, and the content goes pretty darn far considering the Developers still intend to add more to the game. I was kind of expecting to have some issues, but there are no real deadlines imposed by the game itself so it really isn't overwhelming as long as you manage things properly. Nothing makes me happier than coming up with a plan, putting in the work, and finally seeing things to completion with good results. If this is something you can relate to, pickup this game and enjoy the experience.

This game is literally the exact opposite of the "satisfaction" I get from an actual game like Factorio. For a game that relies on 3 dimensions, you would think of the multiple more layers of accessibility in both features and form in comparison to a simplistic 2d factory game like factorio. But alas, it does not.

I've played this game for a total of 100 minutes, and every minute was a seething mess of emotions. The fact that a game with an extra dimension doesn't have something as simplistic as an alignment tool for god sake. Everything you do ends up being an unaligned mess for no reason what so ever. The devs took the time to add an alignment tool to BUILDINGS but nothing else. Why on earth is there a limitation for a basic principle of functionality.

The game has awful collision, so I'm assuming they didn't play test the few first starter items you get to play with at the beginning of the game, considering this was a half arsed mess on release that barely featured anything. The first thing I attempted to do was to jump on top of the player base, only to fall through said base just... because? It's literally THE first item you build and half of it doesn't have collision. Nor does any of the random crashed ships, and nor does have the conveyor belts, as the first thing I did was accidentally place an electric pole through a conveyor belt. And of course, you can just place down electric poles as you please without any consideration of buildings, with the same kind of connection system as Factorio but without the ease of use features such as "Hold down the mouse and drag to automatically place the damn things down". Instead, you have to manually place the pole along the long ass line of conveyor belts you just placed, go back to where you started, and connect each pole INDIVIDUALLY. After 5 years of development your first thought to one of the BASIC features of your game wasn't to make a simple drag system?

The game is a pretty blatant rip off of factorio, even things as simple as crafting speeds and amounts of items you get from crafting things. It's the same basic functionality but even more jank because good luck looking for something as simple as an ore vein, because they are literally impossible to find and you WILL end up spending 20 minutes looking around for them. What the hell are you thinking to not include a simple piece of equipment you can build to help you find ore veins at the beginning of the game, surely if you're to copy something like a game such as Factorio you would consider... I don't know, the extra dimension? Especially when it's a selling point for god sake.

I have no idea why the crafting bench OR the armour bench exist other than to fulfil the purpose of what your inventory crafting should do in most other games, but the difference is that for some reason you can spawn these massive buildings out of the blue, but not a portable miner. Portable is IN the name, I get it's an item, but the fact you have to actively keep messing around going back to these massive work benches for the same thing your inventory can fulfil, then why have the extra step inwhich the massive factory you have generate and sprawl out isn't treated the same way, when I can just use a regular miner. It's annoying and isn't intuitive. Don't make the workstation an entity you can just literally click on, make separate tables and enforce a reason to actively have these different stations, other than just having two for two different arbitrary reasons.

Scrap the factorio comparisons. Minecraft Feed the Beast is a mod pack made by generally anyone who feels like making a mod, on a engine running on Java of all things, in their own time, not IN a studio and developed by ACTUAL game developers. And I will be far enjoy and love playing that more than I enjoy playing this, simply because it isn't a clone, it isn't jank and lazy game design. And, most importantly, it doesn't have the most rail-road factory building systems that rely on the most bog standard tier systems known to man.

The conclusion of my experience is this; this is a lazy, half arsed rip off of a clearly superior game, maybe not in overall features, but DEFINITELY in play-ability and ease of playing the damn game. 100 minutes and the only thing I've learned that this is a over-remembered mess of a game that constantly trips over itself because the devs don't check their own spelling mistakes in their exam. It's a joke. Go back to the basic elements of your game and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fix them, because it's an awful first time experience that feels slow, unimaginative and clunky to play. Play Minecraft FTB or play Factorio, two vastly superior games. Thanks for the refund.

I thought this was going to be a game only about optimizing your factory in an essentially sandbox environment. What I got was a rich game with a very well designed alien world to explore, with subtle messages about environmentalism and the beauty of nature contrasting with the efficiency of machinery. There are literally breathtaking vistas, vast beautiful cave networks, impossible alien landforms, and completely on point music and sound direction. The slightly sinister feeling nature of your FICSIT overlords lends some deep nuance; what are you actually doing here? What role are you playing, and who are you serving?

I'm not an optimizer. I enjoy efficiency, but I'm not one to overdesign to get there, so my bases end up having a naturalistic "base camp" feel, while my friends are building towering factories with rows and rows of machinery. I'm really glad to say, this game supports both playstyles fantastically. I see my friends having a blast designing and organizing monolithic black cubes full of layers and layers of machinery, whereas I love spreading out and nestling my machines in with the trees and cliffs.

The one thing I would dock this game for is that the ecosystem feels too player-focused. I want to see predators chasing prey and fighting other predators for territory. I want to see animals that consume resources, and possibly animals that caretake and develop their own resources as well. This might not be the game for that, and if you're also wanting to see an alien ecosystem spring to life, I highly recommend Subnautica. However, I can't deny the intentional design I feel in segments of this game. Collecting power slugs to me feels like collecting Missile Packs in Metroid. They are usually placed in areas that have a similar challenge feel to them, and are a wonderful reward for exploration. I can't wait to find out what Somersloops and Mercer Spheres are for, because they provide such an intense incentive to explore that I think is missing from some games like this.

There are still bugs and glitches, particularly with enemy AI. It's very rudimentary and when you master kiting enemies, they don't provide that much of a challenge, even with the Xeno-zapper. It's only when they congregate and team up against you that they feel like a challenge. On the other hand, that complexity is used to great effect in the placement of hostile mobs today, so I can't knock the simplistic AI too much because it combines and scales difficulty fairly well, despite the somewhat limited toolkit for designing these encounters.

Also, placing the Space Elevator is a religious experience. I don't care how jaded you are, it's a masterstroke of technology that that sequence plays out so organically and dynamically. You really *feel* the scale of the structure, and it changes the skyline forever.

I feel like there are still some quality of life hiccups around inventory management. As an FPS player, I often find myself hitting the number row to switch my in-hand equipment, only to remember too late that those hotkeys are for your building toolbelt. I'd love a way to switch between modes, even if it just means holding shift while pressing a number gets the build mode quickbar, and just pressing the number equips a new item to your hand slot. On the other hand, there are some very nice Quality of Life touches that I appreciate once I've gotten used to the quirks of this game. Actually placing buildings is decently streamlined, and I appreciate the way building off of foundations allows for a very granular angling. Once you're started building a foundation to fit the area, the 90-degrees snap-to-grid functionality feels very useful. The only complaint I have here is the sometimes janky feeling of trying to get conveyors to snap together. It can be very finicky about what counts as a valid angle, and the feedback isn't always clear about why a conveyor can't be constructed. "Encroaching others' area" ends up being a somewhat frustrating exercise of shimmying things around in minute ways just fiddling to get the lines all connected.

Honestly, though, the game is beautiful enough to warrant the price tag. I don't just mean graphics specifications and technical aptitude. The design of the game's assets and their placement creates spellbinding beauty. The way biomes flow into each other feels extremely organic and immersive, and I've never seen transitions so smooth in any other game. It feels like it surpasses Breath of the Wild in this respect, and some of this may be because setting this on an alien world helps smooth over any strangeness in geology or botany that would subtly break immersion otherwise. There are so many systems in this game to become familiar with, and the tech tree feels so rewarding and rich that it compels me to develop more and more. All in all, this is genius design. Mad respect.

If you have even remotely played Factorio, then you will LOVE this game!

Same vein of factory building on an alien planet, but vastly different on their goals and "story" (if you can call it that). The pure wonder I experienced when first seeing the planet upon planet drop was stunning and the game play flow got me hooked!

Everything is so well designed and intuitive that it just keeps you going hour after hour just like Factorio! One of my favorite parts about this is its vastly dense amount of biomes filled with the richest colors and designs, so much so that I can EASILY spend way too much time exploring in a vehicle or on foot all the nature there is, on such a HUGE map too!

On the factory side of things, machines are easily designed so that they can be tiled and laid out however you wish, and the shear complexity of it all is astounding! Of course, the further you get, the more complex it gets and you will always need to makes tweaks to your base, sometimes tearing it all down and rebuilding!

TL;DR
Great gameplay, stunning visuals, lots to see and explore, COUNTLESS hours of tasty conveyor spaghetti! HIGHLY recommend for fans of the genre!

SO, so many crashes. Once you hit end game its extremely boring and tedious. The most fun was killing the stingers (Spiders) but even the AI is really dumb. The fact you need mods to make the game remotely fun is dumb also.
Hazmat suit that you cant use in gas clouds.
Vehicles that shield you from radiation but not gas clouds.
No way to speed up the game like factorio.
You can breath underwater but not in gas clouds.
Trains take so long to unlock and once you hit cap on local nodes the rest are so far away and railway laying takes a long time.
Drones are expensive and you need at least two per node sometimes 3 to get full efficiency from it.
The ticket sink is frustrating and slow as is stacks and gets harder to get tickets.
Weak weapons that take a while to kill bigger enemies forcing you to fill your inventory.
A bigger inventory is gated behind tiers.
The vehicles chew through fuel. "You are going only 1km to a couple of km's. Yet chews through lots of containers of fuel. SO glad my car doesn't do that or I never go anywhere
Power trips out a lot and can be extremely hard to get running again.
Overall. The game gets boring. It starts feeling like a chore trying to get stuff setup to the point where you stop caring about OCD because you've spent hours trying to get the factory running. Back and forth always getting resources. So many different materials are needed once you hit late tiers is extremely annoying. Most alternate recipes are useless or more expensive. Nodes are capped to belt speed even though you can overclock the miners to be faster, poor game design. The game suffers from extremely bad asset loading lag and is very unoptimised compared to other games using the same game engine. The trains, omg, no signals, clipping through each other, and no conditions like wait times or capacity setting.
Fluid pipes are so buggy and a ridiculous design.
Did I mention crashes? Don't turn off auto save like I did to record stuff for youtube then forget to put it back on. I lost a few hours of gameplay from game crashes and forgetting to save.

I can't go on grinding this game any longer. It's just so boring.

Satisfactory is a beautiful hand crafted game for fans of industrial simulation games like Factorio, Dyson Sphere Program, etc..
Other than just crafting, there is also exploration and combat. Beautiful biomes to discover.

A beautiful factory building experience that scales up at a digestible and rewarding pace. The game begins with you using a pickaxe to mine ore and by the end of ten hours, you are automating and optimizing that process well more than 100x over. In order to accomplish your objectives, this scenario of 'scaling up' ensues at a seemingly sigmoidal growth rate (only if you're up to the task of setting up the necessary infrastructure.)

The exploration expands over treacherous territory- sudden pitfalls, steep cliff sides that rise up hundreds of meters, monsters that defend sought after upgrades, and resources that are great distances apart from one another. The objective is to create a network of factories that utilize the extraction and production from those resources in the most efficient way possible. If that sounds more like work than like gaming to you, then you might be right, because there is no shortage of online-manual-labor required to set up your brilliantly designed automated networks.

But don't be scared away- there is a peaceful aura to the scenery, a pleasing-to-the-ears synthwave-esque soundtrack. The mechanics are polished; the player has the mobility of a fast-paced FPS- able to sprint, jump, slide, fly, and drive, and wields no shortage of tools to play with. Moments of adversity are obscured by the serenity gleaned from looking out over your creations from far away and acknowledging the imprint your technology has made on the landscape.

In the overall process of completing the game, there are milestones to overcome represented by the newest and most difficult products to manufacture, which truthfully challenge your ability to manage your resources and time.

Totally worth the $30 USD to enjoy the game and support an awesome development team.
Highly recommend playing with a friend.

Disclaimer: IRL fluid dynamics and hydrostatics not included

Satisfactory for me is a game which is enjoyable to play. Due to two reasons:
Firstly, there is a gigantic world to explore. So far I have been in caves, valleys, desert, plains, lake, and swamp. As an example, the graphic of the coral texture area has the most detail.
Secondly, the highly realistic and highly customizable building construction makes the player so satisfy to experience. Like the belts.
Since this game we play is Beta version (not finished game). I strongly suggest the game to add more varieties on minerals. Perhaps each mineral will only have only have a few recipes, this can allow the game to have more variables and interesting for experience to play. Moreover, adding some creature that produce bio martial is also recommended. This can add farming gameplay in the game which I think will be popular and interesting to play.

At this time, I can't recommend the game. Without a lot of mods, it's just another nondescript factory building game. There is no end goal to aim for, just having things automated and optimised to prevent bottlenecks is the only aim the game has. The animals that attack you have a very basic AI which is far too easy to predict and counter and you only need to obtain the next weapon up to become practically invincible, you don't even need the rifle.

Sorry, but at this stage in time, it needs a LOT of work to make it worth playing in my view.

Overall Score 4/5
Satisfactory feels significant in the space it takes. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time playing and the blend between survival and factory building is executed amazingly.

Performance 3/5
At times when there are a lot of objects or buildings on screen, lag can start to creep in and cause stuttering. This doesn't happen too often and techniques such as hiding conveyor belts behind walls so that they aren't visible can help to alleviate the issue. However, during an autosave, the lag is noticeable and annoying no matter where you are on the map. Besides these issues, I manage to maintain high frames consistently with no issue and have yet to see my CPU or GPU throttle.


The gameplay feels smooth and so far I have come across a few fun glitches. I will say, that for an early access title, Satisfactory feels a lot more polished than others in recent memory. This game is what I wish Space Engineers played like, the graphics are clean and the building feels intuitive. When I have researched a new tier or construct a newly unlocked building for the first time, it truly feels like an accomplishment. The sense of satisfaction from automating a process that was once laborious is incredible and provides a real drive to play. The lack of a story aspect is bolstered by a growing world with a unique design and clear-cut goals that reward you with useful and significant upgrades.


The community that has been built around Satisfactory is accepting and altogether fun to be in. Players on forums and gathering places such as r/Satisfactory are kind and engaging. Sometimes it feels like it might take an architectural or engineering degree to sort out how to make the shiny new item you are after, but taking a step back and referring to the well-made guides and help from devoted players you will make it along fine. This attitude is reflected in a group of Devs that are committed to their craft and truly listen to their players. Their updates are always well anticipated and bring exciting features that add new horizons to the game for your creativity to explore.

Build stuff, in order to build stuff, that unlocks new tech that lets you build stuff.

Exploration is always amazing. Huge focus on movement and verticality. Jet packs, vehicles, jump pads, hyper tubes, trains, etc. Exploration is so good it rivals minecraft despite having a single map (albeit large).

This isn't factorio. It's less technical, easier to get into, more colourful. AND. The vertical elements bring a whole new feel to bases. Being able to ship things upwards, or create 3D factory cubes really let's your creativity for efficient design.. SHINE.

TL;DR DRINK COFFEE. PLAY GAEM.

Satisfactory is a game about running from the past. Your worst enemy in this game on a hostile alien planet is not the local fauna, but yourself anywhere from 2 to 12 hours ago. Because what moron would set their machines up this way? Why are they pointing the wrong direction? Why don't you have enough power? *Where are you going to get the resources for this next part!?* You don't know, but you know that you 12 hours ago knew even less, and because of that you have to deal with the consequences of their ill-thought-out actions.
Addictive, fun and lots of playability :). A good one if you like logistics, maths and sandbox games. Think a more mathematical adult focused version of Minecraft. Also the developers are hilarious.

THIS GAME IS AMAZING!!!!!! I don't know if it's just me, but for the last few years I feel there has been a real lack of imagination when it comes to game making. There has been some very big name game releases that I have looked forward to, and yet once they get released and you play for a few days or so, you've played through it all and these developers now-a-days TOTALLY FORGET ABOUT THE GAMES. They make their big chunk of money on the release and never go in and update content or add new things. These big companies release these huge games with so much potential, but they're only out for a dollar. Even if/when they release updates.. they want you to pay stupid amounts of money for them, and if you don't then you are left with a very vanilla game.

This game however, is constantly coming out with releases and new updates... I have put in close to 200 hours and I am still learning something new everyday, and there's soooooo much more to unlock! I've put that 200 hours in and that's just the first game I started with! There are more maps!!! I think you could truly spend a lifetime playing this game and still have things to do and learn.. and it's still in the early release stage!!!!!

I haven't been addicted to a game like this in years.. it brings back memories of the old COD Modern Warfare and Battlefield 3 days when ALL responsibilities went to the side because I couldn't put enough hours in! First time in a long time I have rushed home to play a game.. it actually gives me something to look forward to!! Even at work I am sitting there thinking of ways to improve my systems and what I'll do next!!!!!

GET THIS GAME, BUT BE WARNED YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO STOP!!!!

Big shout out to the mods and developers who continue to put time into this game and have finally sparked my gaming passion again! I would buy this game 10x over again, and not even for the new content.. but out of the principal that you can tell these guys want to make us happy and ensure we continue to love the game! That's worth something!

BUY IT!!!!

At the time of writing this, the game has a "Overwhemingly Positive" rating. I feel this is overly generous. So to balance it out I will vote to not "recommend". Steam, please change your voting system.

Like other and very few negative reviews have pointed out, and I feel this is a bit unfair, but we live in the real world where a different game and probably the inspiration for this game exists, by the name of Factorio. Factorio is a game that better captures the essence of what Satisfactory is trying to accomplish.

What do I mean by this? Well, you need to place down buildings and transport stuff between them using conveyors, right? So this translates into a space management problem and playing this game in first person is a fatal flaw. It's very difficult to judge space in first person. This is why in real life we use things like plans on a piece of paper, which allows us to allocate space easily. It's like the idea started a gimmick: What if we could see our Factorio factory in first person, wouldn't that be cool? And then they made the game that way, missing the entire point. It's a step backwards down in game mechanics. If they add a top down view via a drone and a out of the box grid system, it would help greatly.

I found the game to be much simpler than Factorio, but way more tedious. Especially with manually having to collect fuel leaves to power your installation. You can't even hold it down. You have to hit your use key on every single flower. And you need THOUSANDS of them. My finger actually started to hurt. That can't be good for my hands...

It's not a bad game. It's better than average. It's probably even good. But it's definitely not "overwhemingly" so. It's not overwhemingly anything.

7 / 10

I can't express how great this game is. This is a true masterpiece of game development and is worth every dollar.

You can see yourself grow in this game, not just through the progression of the tier system but also through your own logic and problem solving skills. Each production line you set up will be better and you eventually see the pitfalls of your original implementation. You then can choose to refactor the setup completely or make slight adjustments to improve efficiency.

It is an amazing brain exercise. I can't remember the last time a game made me pull out a piece of paper to calculate and design something to be done in game.

If you have even the slightest interest, I say... just do it! You won't regret it.

Have you ever wondered how good you are at running a factory in the most chaotic fashion?
Like automating things?
You have no problem slaughtering local wildlife and destroying entire forests to get faster conveyor belts?

Then this game is for you!

Come in and enjoy what it would be like if you were productive and efficient!

Built stuff!
destroy stuff!
Build more stuff!
Wonder why 10 hours of your life just flew by...

And if your feeling that big 'ol pal, existential dread...
Then don't worry, there is always a faster conveyor belt!

It's okay.

It's not as refined as factorio and there seems to be a prevailing belief that the player wants to redesign their factories about 8 times before the end of the game.

Belting, splitting and merging could be handled better because certain resources like screws get used A LOT and the belts can't keep up in a single line and multi line are a pain in the ass to implement compared to factorio.

I'm not sold on the alternate recipes being "discovered" on hard drives. I feel like you should be able to research them or buy them from the sink shop to help reduce the randomness.

Game is still Early access. Single player is okay, but multi-player, it's noticeable. Lots of texture glitches with belts, rendered water that will kill you if you jump into it and areas you can fall through the map, make you not want to explore because you can lose everything in your inventory.

But of course you have to because of the Hard drive and power slug system.

At the time of this writing, this is the only game I'm playing. It's been a two months since I've played another another game. I probably should play something else to avoid burn out.

So thinking about playing another game then makes me think of all the things I need to do in the game. I actually have a task list written down on what I want to accomplish. That usually goes to hell when I get into the game and get distracted by something else I wanted to do. This game really focuses on efficiency of the machines you chain together but I'm definitely not running at 100% efficiency ;).

So the building aspect of this game is good but I'm not that good with design and mostly just stick with square and rectangle shaped buildings. The features of the game that I love the most is product automation and logistics. Regarding the latter, trains was a big game changer for me. This has allowed me to consolidate all the items I have in different parts of the world and I'm working on my first mega base too.

If any of this is what you like then this is the game for you and I hope this review helps you make that decision to play.

There are only 3 types of gathering objects that improve base(all with the same skin but different color.) There are only 3 enemy classes. Those that shoot you, those that attack you, and those that HOLY OMG WHAT IS IT (BURN IT WITH FIRE.)
And while that is fun. I would like to see further variation on enemies. As well as cute little animals you could befriend. There is only one of those.
I'd also like to see and expanse into the areas you might enjoy. So if you build until endgame (which I have NOT currently reached.) I'd like to see more opportunity/purpose/reason for building (missions, milestones, and rewards.) My current insensitive for building is OMG this is so cool. But I can imagine a game, exactly like this, that gives me incentive(in the form of more content,) as I mentioned.

So to recap. Game is a solid 9/10 or 10/10 game, even in its current version. But
You need varied enemies. Not just what it has now. (Water enemies are an idea, as well as a weapon to fight those, however those may get annoying too. So probably bad idea, just brainstorming here.)
You need more of a research tree that is harder, but gives a better reward. (It just sort of takes 3 seconds for to Finnish almost half of it and progression feels cheap. Its called "The MAM" but its a research tree.)
You need to give more options for varried buildings and building types. Its not "barebones" however, i'd love to see this game grow with a direction of say "creative mode." Or, "creative lobbies." As well as more buildable items to meet those modes head on. I believe more stuff to build would expand the world into the realm of WOW THIS IS EPIC instead of just OMG This is cool.

There are probably a million ways to improve the game, but I understand the game they gave me. I love the game they gave me. But even if you play, 24 hours or less, you'll realize, this game is AWESOME
Even if you don't have some suggestions, like me, on what they could improve, even if your critical of gameplay, even if you're thinking, should I buy this? The fun of this game, comes from playing this game. Exploring this game, and building in this game. An area you never knew, eventually becomes a base, or a part of your base. Its truly unique, as I have NEVER played a game like this. Buy this game.

I enjoyed some of my time in Satisfactory, but I never got past tier 4 industry because I felt gated behind... building a factory. I enjoy the progression and the exploration, but I don't actually enjoy the factory-building portion of the game. The size of the machines and my closeness to them makes placement and arrangement difficult and tedious for me. I think the game would be greatly improved by a build mode in which is more like a city-builder top-down view. Of course I've heard that there's some kind of hover building thing later, but I haven't gotten to it. Maybe if that was moved to earlier in the progression I could enjoy the factory building.

Moreover there seems to be no overarching reason for progression and factory building other than for their own sake. There's no goal, no real threats (i.e. the bug attackers in Factorio), no point to doing anything other than the enjoyment of doing it.

Great game with incredible art design and performance. But personally I found it difficult to really enjoy.

A critically addicting factory building sandbox with a dash of exploration and crazy environments. The game's progression system is brilliantly implemented in a way that makes sure you always have a goal to work towards, but enough freedom in how you want to accomplish it that you never lose the feel of a sandbox experience. Once you get the swing of the mechanics and start unlocking more buildings, tech, and cool gadgets, the game takes a thrilling spin and becomes a huge management sim of the coolest type.

Can't recommend enough, just be prepared to waste many, many evenings away trying to perfect the efficiency of your Heavy Modular Frame factory.

Strangely addictive game play.

At first you are just running around exploring what can be done. Then you begin to realize the largest limitation is your own preconceived restrictions. There is no box... don't try to think within one.

Yes, floors can float with nothing supporting them. Floors are the key to building vertically because they allow you to build above structures without being blocked.

Automation is the key. Then you find that the amount of resources required for more advanced items will change all your ratios of items you thought you needed to build earlier.

Honestly, I generally don't leave reviews, but this game is interesting, addictive, sandboxy, challenging and rewarding.

Open world, survival base building, tech tree researching, resource balancing satisfaction.

You start on an alien world, dig up resources, arrange electricity, automate resources (smelting, making rods etc) then go from there, increasing your tech tree from making screws to nuclear fuel control rods.

To be honest, you won't regret playing this, not at first at least. A quick session may end up accidentally leaving you tired in the morning following 4 hours sleep.

I don't usually write reviews, but this game deserves it: everything about it is just perfect! There are so many aspects of it to keep you fully engaged: resource hunting, creating new production lines and improving old ones and unlocking new materials and recipes through the tiers, space elevator and research.

This game is masterfully crafted, there is never a moment of boredom because there is always something new to do: improving the power grid because you put down new machines that build new components, meaning you need to tweak your old production line to make it more efficient and maybe hunt down some resource nodes to upgrade your raw material input.

The progression is also very well engineered: you start from zero, having to do everything manually until you can automate the process and then, as you unlock more things, the production lines get more and more complex, requiring some clever thinking and planning to make it as efficient as possible.

There is also a multiplayer aspect, so you can build your factories with friends, even though I personally don't care for that.

And the game isn't even finished yet! But it is already so great! I very highly recommend this game!

I don't even know where to begin, this game is amazing, no need to wait for the full release, there is a ton of content to play through as is. Don't expect any story or even an in depth campaign, it's more of a sandbox with some overarching goals but chasing those goals is incredibly fun and addictive.

While the world is quite large and pretty to look at, the combat and exploration is a bit shallow, however the real meat of this game is in planning and constructing the most efficient mega factories that you can dream up. The building systems seem simple at first but as you unlock more elements to build with the possibilities open up quite a bit, throw in vehicles and all sorts of character equipment like parachutes and jetpacks for some added fun and it's a nearly perfect mix. I've been playing for over 300 hours across both steam and the original release on the epic store and I still find myself daydreaming about it all the time.

Delightfully complex and beautiful, with a rich tech tree and amazing graphics. If you want a peaceful building experience, Be sure to get the Satisfactory Mod Manager application so you can turn off enemies (search for passive mode). This made the game 10x more fun for me, and I enjoyed many late nights solving production puzzles, exploring the lovely world, and creating a giant mega factory city without the stress of having to kill or be killed. I love this game!
